summary: Medullary thyroid cancer is a form of thyroid carcinoma originating from the parafollicular cells (C cells) of the thyroid gland, which produce the hormone calcitonin. It is the third most common type of thyroid cancer, accounting for about 3% of all cases. Approximately 25% of MTC cases are genetic, caused by mutations in the RET proto-oncogene, and can be associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN2). Sporadic MTC accounts for the remaining 75% of cases.
causes: Somatic mutation of the RET proto-oncogene (sporadic)
risk_factors: Genetic conditions, including multiple endocrine neoplasia
Family history of thyroid cancer or thyroid disease
Exposure to certain types of radiation
symptoms: Hoarseness or other changes to voice
diagnosis: Fine needle aspiration of thyroid lesion
Microscopic examination of amyloid stroma with hyperplasia of parafollicular cells
treatments: Total thyroidectomy with bilateral neck dissection
Radioactive iodine therapy (not for medullary type)
subtypes: Medullary thyroid cancer associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2A
Medullary thyroid cancer associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2B
